elements.content: A novel metal-organic framework with one-dimensional channels {[Cd(3)(CH3COO)2(H2O)2] (CH3CN)x(CH3OH)y} (5), based on conformationally restricted linear 4,4′-bis(1-imidazolyl)biphenyl (3) and cadmium acetate dihydrate, has been synthesized. It crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P1̅ with a = 5.6528(11) Å, b = 9.887(3) Å, c = 12.924(3) Å, and Z = 1. The experimental results demonstrate that coordinated crystal water molecules may play a key role in the formation of the metal-organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: A novel metal-organic framework with one-dimensional channels {[Cd(3)(CH3COO)2(H2O)2] (CH3CN)x(CH3OH)y} (5), based on conformationally restricted linear 4,4'-bis(1-imidazolyl)biphenyl (3) and cadmium acetate dihydrate, has been synthesized. It crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P1̅ with a = 5.6528(11) Å, b = 9.887(3) Å, c = 12.924(3) Å, and Z = 1. The experimental results demonstrate that coordinated crystal water molecules may play a key role in the formation of the metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content: A novel metal-organic framework with one-dimensional channels {[Cd(3)(CH3COO)2(H2O)2] (CH3CN)x(CH3OH)y} (5), based on conformationally restricted linear 4,4′-bis(1-imidazolyl)biphenyl (3) and cadmium acetate dihydrate, has been synthesized. The experimental results demonstrate that coordinated crystal water molecules may play a key role in the formation of the metal-organic frameworks.
elements.clean_text: A novel metal-organic framework with one-dimensional channels {[Cd(3)(CH3COO)2(H2O)2] (CH3CN)x(CH3OH)y} (5), based on conformationally restricted linear 4,4'-bis(1-imidazolyl)biphenyl (3) and cadmium acetate dihydrate, has been synthesized. The experimental results demonstrate that coordinated crystal water molecules may play a key role in the formation of the metal-organic frameworks.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with channels is currently a highly active area of investigation because of their intriguing structures and, more importantly, their potential applications in gas storage, molecular sieves, ion exchange, and catalysis. It is well-known that the construction of such materials strongly depends on the nature of organic bridging units and metal ions as well as counteranions. In this regard, considerable attentions have been devoted to the design of new functional N-heterocyclic organic bridging units. Among the examples reported, linear, rigid, and bifunctional bridging ligands with an adjustable arene core have been found to be one of the most versatile building blocks. For instance, Fujita and co-workers successfully assembled 4,4′-bis(4-pyridyl)biphenyl (1, Scheme ) and Ni(NO3)2 into an extraordinarily large square-grid polymer with dimensions of up to 20 × 20 Å, which further packed and created big rectangular channels (ca. 10 × 20 Å). Similarly, utilizing a rigid chiral bridging ligand containing orthogonal pyridinyl groups (2), Lin et al. obtained a series of homochiral channels. On the other hand, imidazoles as building blocks are currently attracting special interest in the area of supramolecular chemistry because of their importance in biology and biochemistry. In virtue of imidazole and its derivatives with flexible structures, many MOFs with interesting topologies (e.g., one-dimensional (1D) chains or channels, two-dimensional (2D) networks and three-dimensional (3D) architectures, etc.) have been documented. However, there are only few reports describing the MOFs with rigid imidazole-containing linkers, although the ligand rigidity facilitates the control in the design and assembly of the resulting metal-containing aggregates. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, the examples describing MOFs with channels arising from rigid imidazole units are relatively rare so far. Following our continuing interest in the development of imidazole chemistry, we herein present a new kind of channel-like metal-organic framework constructed by 4,4′-bis(1-imidazolyl)biphenyl (3) and cadmium acetate dihydrate. Our results indicate that the coordinated crystal water molecules of metal salts, like organic bridging units, metal ions, and their counteranions, may play a vital role in controlling the topologies of resulting materials.
elements.clean_text: The design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with channels is currently a highly active area of investigation because of their intriguing structures and, more importantly, their potential applications in gas storage, molecular sieves, ion exchange, and catalysis. It is well-known that the construction of such materials strongly depends on the nature of organic bridging units and metal ions as well as counteranions. In this regard, considerable attentions have been devoted to the design of new functional N-heterocyclic organic bridging units. Among the examples reported, linear, rigid, and bifunctional bridging ligands with an adjustable arene core have been found to be one of the most versatile building blocks. For instance, Fujita and co-workers successfully assembled 4,4'-bis(4-pyridyl)biphenyl (1, Scheme ) and Ni(NO3)2 into an extraordinarily large square-grid polymer with dimensions of up to 20 × 20 Å, which further packed and created big rectangular channels (ca. 10 × 20 Å). Similarly, utilizing a rigid chiral bridging ligand containing orthogonal pyridinyl groups (2), Lin et al. obtained a series of homochiral channels. On the other hand, imidazoles as building blocks are currently attracting special interest in the area of supramolecular chemistry because of their importance in biology and biochemistry. In virtue of imidazole and its derivatives with flexible structures, many MOFs with interesting topologies (e.g., one-dimensional (1D) chains or channels, two-dimensional (2D) networks and three-dimensional (3D) architectures, etc.) have been documented. However, there are only few reports describing the MOFs with rigid imidazole-containing linkers, although the ligand rigidity facilitates the control in the design and assembly of the resulting metal-containing aggregates. Moreover, to the best of our knowledge, the examples describing MOFs with channels arising from rigid imidazole units are relatively rare so far. Following our continuing interest in the development of imidazole chemistry, we herein present a new kind of channel-like metal-organic framework constructed by 4,4'-bis(1-imidazolyl)biphenyl (3) and cadmium acetate dihydrate. Our results indicate that the coordinated crystal water molecules of metal salts, like organic bridging units, metal ions, and their counteranions, may play a vital role in controlling the topologies of resulting materials.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Chemical Structures of Ligands <bold>1</bold>−<bold>3</bold>
</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gs1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2008-00038j_0006.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

In our initial study, anhydrous cadmium acetate was employed to react with the rigid bidentate ligand 3. Slow evaporation of the methanol/acetonitrile solution of cadmium acetate and 3 in a 1:1 molar ratio yielded single crystals of [Cd(3)(CH3COO)2] (4) suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The asymmetric unit of 4 shows that the cadmium atom adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Every cadmium is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogen atoms from two different 3, two oxygen atoms from the same acetate anion, and two oxygen atoms from two different acetate ions, whose other oxygen atoms serve as bridging positions to connect the adjacent identical cadmium ion, leading to the formation of one-dimensional infinite ladderlike chains (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: In our initial study, anhydrous cadmium acetate was employed to react with the rigid bidentate ligand 3. Slow evaporation of the methanol/acetonitrile solution of cadmium acetate and 3 in a 1:1 molar ratio yielded single crystals of [Cd(3)(CH3COO)2] (4) suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The asymmetric unit of 4 shows that the cadmium atom adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. Every cadmium is coordinated by two imidazole nitrogen atoms from two different 3, two oxygen atoms from the same acetate anion, and two oxygen atoms from two different acetate ions, whose other oxygen atoms serve as bridging positions to connect the adjacent identical cadmium ion, leading to the formation of one-dimensional infinite ladderlike chains (Figure ).

elements.content: (a) Asymmetric unit of 4, showing 30% thermal ellipsoid probability. (b) One-dimensional infinite ladder-like chains of 4. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Asymmetric unit of 4, showing 30% thermal ellipsoid probability. (b) One-dimensional infinite ladder-like chains of 4. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Interestingly, the usage of Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O instead of Cd(CH3COO)2 gave rise to a new complex {[Cd(3)(CH3COO)2(H2O)2]·(CH3CN) x (CH3OH) y } (5) with a quite different topology. As shown in Figure a, the cadmium atom resides in an ideal octahedral environment with two oxygen atoms from two water molecules at the apical positions (O−Cd−O = 180°), and two oxygen atoms from different acetate anions and two nitrogen atoms from two different 3 at the equatorial positions. The other imidazole nitrogen of the bidentate 3 is connected to another cadmium through the Cd−N coordination bond, resulting in one-dimensional chains, which are further linked by intermolecular O−H···O hydrogen bonds (O1···O2 = 2.773 Å, O1−H1···O2 = 164.9°) to expand to two-dimensional layers (Figure b). Each layer is in van der Waals contact with two neighboring layers, which leads to three-dimensional networks. More interestingly, the chain aggregates are stacked along the crystallographic a axis to create large one-dimensional channels, which are filled with disordered solvent molecules (Figure ). Omitting guest molecules, the vacant channels of 5 are approximately rectangular in crosssection with internal van der Waals dimensions of ca. 4 × 10.5 Å2. The solvent-accessible volume of 5 calculated using PLATON is 22.0%, which belongs to the moderate dimensions compared to the documented reports. In comparison with complex 4, the crystal water molecules clearly play a key role in the formation of channel structure. When two orbitals of cadmium(II) at the apical positions are occupied by two crystal water molecules, the acetate ions have to adopt the unidentate coordination mode, instead of the bidentate four-membered chelate ringlike complex 4, to complete the octahedral coordination geometry of cadmium(II).
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the usage of Cd(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O instead of Cd(CH3COO)2 gave rise to a new complex {[Cd(3)(CH3COO)2(H2O)2]⋅(CH3CN) x (CH3OH) y } (5) with a quite different topology. As shown in Figure a, the cadmium atom resides in an ideal octahedral environment with two oxygen atoms from two water molecules at the apical positions (O-Cd-O = 180°), and two oxygen atoms from different acetate anions and two nitrogen atoms from two different 3 at the equatorial positions. The other imidazole nitrogen of the bidentate 3 is connected to another cadmium through the Cd-N coordination bond, resulting in one-dimensional chains, which are further linked by intermolecular O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (O1⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.773 Å, O1-H1⋅⋅⋅O2 = 164.9°) to expand to two-dimensional layers (Figure b). Each layer is in van der Waals contact with two neighboring layers, which leads to three-dimensional networks. More interestingly, the chain aggregates are stacked along the crystallographic a axis to create large one-dimensional channels, which are filled with disordered solvent molecules (Figure ). Omitting guest molecules, the vacant channels of 5 are approximately rectangular in crosssection with internal van der Waals dimensions of ca. 4 × 10.5 Å2. The solvent-accessible volume of 5 calculated using PLATON is 22.0%, which belongs to the moderate dimensions compared to the documented reports. In comparison with complex 4, the crystal water molecules clearly play a key role in the formation of channel structure. When two orbitals of cadmium(II) at the apical positions are occupied by two crystal water molecules, the acetate ions have to adopt the unidentate coordination mode, instead of the bidentate four-membered chelate ringlike complex 4, to complete the octahedral coordination geometry of cadmium(II).

elements.content: (a) Coordination mode of cadmium atom of 5, showing 30% thermal ellipsoid probability. All hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) Infinite 2D layers connected by O−H···O hydrogen bonds (orange dashed line).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination mode of cadmium atom of 5, showing 30% thermal ellipsoid probability. All hydrogen atoms and solvent molecules were omitted for clarity. (b) Infinite 2D layers connected by O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (orange dashed line).

elements.content: (a) Perspective view of a 1D channel of 5 viewed along the [010] direction. The host frameworks are shown as wire-frame, and the disordered solvent molecules are shown in the space-filling; the pink polyhedrons represent coordination mode of cadmium atoms. (b) Space-filling projection showing the packing arrangement of 5 host complexes to form large rectangular channels along the a axis.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Perspective view of a 1D channel of 5 viewed along the [010] direction. The host frameworks are shown as wire-frame, and the disordered solvent molecules are shown in the space-filling; the pink polyhedrons represent coordination mode of cadmium atoms. (b) Space-filling projection showing the packing arrangement of 5 host complexes to form large rectangular channels along the a axis.

elements.content: To further investigate the effect of crystal water molecules on the structure of aggregates, we added additional water directly to the reaction mixture of anhydrous cadmium acetate and 3 in methanol/acetonitrile. X-ray diffraction analysis of the resulting complex [Cd(3)(CH3COO)2(H2O)] (6) indicates that only one water molecule participates in the coordination with Cd(II), which could not lead to the formation of the channel-like MOF 5. In 6, the cadmium ion adopts a seven-coordinated pentagonal bipyramidal geometry; one oxygen atom from water coordinates to the metal center, and the other six coordination points are taken by two bidentate acetate anions and two imidazole groups, resulting in the formation of infinite one-dimensional coordination polymer chains (Figure a). There are intermolecular O−H···O hydrogen bonds between water molecules and acetate anions to stabilize these chains with O5···O3 = 2.73 Å, O5−H1···O3 = 171° and O5···O2 = 2.74 Å, O5−H2···O5 = 165°, which produce two-dimensional networks as illustrated in Figure b. Very interestingly, the MOF 5 was obtained as additional water was added to the reaction mixture of cadmium acetate dihydrate and 3 in methanol/acetonitrile. These experiments demonstrate that there exists the competitive coordination of acetate anions and water molecules with cadmium(II). Clearly, the formation of the expected 1D channels requests the preferential occupation of two orbitals of cadmium(II) at the apical positions by two crystal water molecules. Otherwise, acetate anions have a tendency toward the bidentate coordination mode like 4 and 6. Furthermore, the concentration-dependent studies were performed to prove the dependency on the water of crystallization of the metal salt. The experimental results indicate that the concentrations of reaction mixtures did not affect the structures of the aggregates formed. It is well-known that most metal salts contain crystal water molecules. However, there have been rare discussions with regard to their influence on the topologies of metal-organic frameworks. This study, albeit performed on only a kind of metal compounds, indicates that crystal water molecules should be considered as an important factor in the design of metal-organic structures. It should be noted that this type of crystal water-dependent self-assembly is different from those with water molecules filled in the channels.

X-ray diffraction analysis of the resulting complex [Cd(3)(CH3COO)2(H2O)] (6) indicates that only one water molecule participates in the coordination with Cd(II), which could not lead to the formation of the channel-like MOF 5. In 6, the cadmium ion adopts a seven-coordinated pentagonal bipyramidal geometry; one oxygen atom from water coordinates to the metal center, and the other six coordination points are taken by two bidentate acetate anions and two imidazole groups, resulting in the formation of infinite one-dimensional coordination polymer chains (Figure a). There are intermolecular O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between water molecules and acetate anions to stabilize these chains with O5⋅⋅⋅O3 = 2.73 Å, O5-H1⋅⋅⋅O3 = 171° and O5⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.74 Å, O5-H2⋅⋅⋅O5 = 165°, which produce two-dimensional networks as illustrated in Figure b. Very interestingly, the MOF 5 was obtained as additional water was added to the reaction mixture of cadmium acetate dihydrate and 3 in methanol/acetonitrile. These experiments demonstrate that there exists the competitive coordination of acetate anions and water molecules with cadmium(II). Clearly, the formation of the expected 1D channels requests the preferential occupation of two orbitals of cadmium(II) at the apical positions by two crystal water molecules. Otherwise, acetate anions have a tendency toward the bidentate coordination mode like 4 and 6. Furthermore, the concentration-dependent studies were performed to prove the dependency on the water of crystallization of the metal salt. The experimental results indicate that the concentrations of reaction mixtures did not affect the structures of the aggregates formed. It is well-known that most metal salts contain crystal water molecules. However, there have been rare discussions with regard to their influence on the topologies of metal-organic frameworks. This study, albeit performed on only a kind of metal compounds, indicates that crystal water molecules should be considered as an important factor in the design of metal-organic structures. It should be noted that this type of crystal water-dependent self-assembly is different from those with water molecules filled in the channels.

elements.content: (a) Thermal ellipsoids plot (30% probability level) of 6. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. (b) Infinite 2D networks of 6. Orange dashed lines indicate O−H···O hydrogen bonds.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Thermal ellipsoids plot (30% probability level) of 6. Hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity. (b) Infinite 2D networks of 6. Orange dashed lines indicate O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have described a new type of channel-like metal-organic framework based on a conformationally restricted linear imidazole bridging unit and cadmium acetate dihydrate. This crystal water-dependent supramolecular self-assembly would give helpful clues to the design of novel functional MOFs. Further studies with respect to the effect of crystal water molecules of other metal salts on the structure of aggregates are now in progress in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have described a new type of channel-like metal-organic framework based on a conformationally restricted linear imidazole bridging unit and cadmium acetate dihydrate. This crystal water-dependent supramolecular self-assembly would give helpful clues to the design of novel functional MOFs. Further studies with respect to the effect of crystal water molecules of other metal salts on the structure of aggregates are now in progress in our laboratory.

elements.content: The purities of bulk samples of crystals 4 and 6 were determined through comparison of experimental and simulated PXRD patterns. Their experimental patterns favorably correlate with the corresponding simulated ones generated from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. Unfortunately, crystal 5 immediately collapsed after being removed from the mother liquor, and reliable powder X-ray as well as elemental analysis data could not be obtained thereby. See Figures S1 and S2 in the

elements.content: The exact number of guest molecules (solvents) in the crystallographic asymmetry unit can not be determined according to the Fourier electron-densities because of disorder. However, the host framework can be located exactly.
